issues.title: Possible Posting Issue
issues.body:
The following error was observed by a SeaMonkey build script posting to the API

```
/d/sources/users/Callek_gmail.com/tools/release /d/sources/braindump/releases-related
Adding product: SeaMonkey-2.15b3
Server response:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><products><product id="2190" name="SeaMonkey-2.15b3"/></products>
Adding product: SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Complete
Server response:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><products><product id="2191" name="SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Complete"/></products>
Adding product: SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Partial-2.15b2
Server response:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><products><product id="2192" name="SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Partial-2.15b2"/></prod
ucts>
Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3, linux: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/linux-i686/:lang/seamonkey-2.15b3.tar.bz2

Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Complete, linux: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/update/linux-i686/:lang/seamonke
y-2.15b3.complete.mar
Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Partial-2.15b2, linux: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/update/linux-i686/:lang/se
amonkey-2.15b2-2.15b3.partial.mar
Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3, osx: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/mac/:lang/SeaMonkey%202.15b3.dmg
Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Complete, osx: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/update/mac/:lang/seamonkey-2.15b3.
complete.mar
Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Partial-2.15b2, osx: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/update/mac/:lang/seamonkey-2
.15b2-2.15b3.partial.mar
Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3, win: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/win32/:lang/SeaMonkey%20Setup%202.15b3.exe
Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Complete, win: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/update/win32/:lang/seamonkey-2.15b
3.complete.mar
Adding location for SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Partial-2.15b2, win: /seamonkey/releases/2.15b3/update/win32/:lang/seamonkey
-2.15b2-2.15b3.partial.mar
FAILED: Tuxedo API error. URL: https://bounceradmin.mozilla.com/api/location_add/
POST data: path=%2Fseamonkey%2Freleases%2F2.15b3%2Fupdate%2Fwin32%2F%3Alang%2Fseamonkey-2.15b2-2.15b3.partial.mar
&product=SeaMonkey-2.15b3-Partial-2.15b2&os=win
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tuxedo-add.py", line 147, in tuxedoRequest
    return urllib2.urlopen(request).read()
  File "d:\mozilla-build\python\lib\urllib2.py", line 126, in urlopen
    return _opener.open(url, data, timeout)
  File "d:\mozilla-build\python\lib\urllib2.py", line 391, in open
    response = self._open(req, data)
  File "d:\mozilla-build\python\lib\urllib2.py", line 409, in _open
    '_open', req)
  File "d:\mozilla-build\python\lib\urllib2.py", line 369, in _call_chain
    result = func(*args)
  File "d:\mozilla-build\python\lib\urllib2.py", line 1169, in https_open
    return self.do_open(httplib.HTTPSConnection, req)
  File "d:\mozilla-build\python\lib\urllib2.py", line 1136, in do_open
    raise URLError(err)
URLError: <urlopen error [Errno 10060] A connection attempt failed because the connected party did not properly r
espond after a period of time, or established connection failed because connected host has failed to respond>
```

The following traceback was observed being logged on the web server that handled the POST

```
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error] [client 10.8.81.216] (70014)End of file found: mod_wsgi (pid=7611): Unable to get bucket brigade for request.
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [debug] mod_headers.c(768): headers: ap_headers_error_filter()
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error] ERROR:django.request:Internal Server Error: /api/location_add/
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error] Traceback (most recent call last):
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/core/handlers/base.py", line 111, in get_response
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     response = callback(request, *callback_args, **callback_kwargs)
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/views/decorators/http.py", line 41, in inner
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     return func(request, *args, **kwargs)
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/views/decorators/csrf.py", line 77, in wrapped_view
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     return view_func(*args, **kwargs)
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/apps/api/decorators.py", line 63, in wrapper
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     realm, *args, **kwargs)
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/apps/api/decorators.py", line 103, in _view_or_basicauth
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     return view(request, *args, **kwargs)
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/apps/api/views.py", line 305, in location_add
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     prodname = request.POST.get('product', None)
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/core/handlers/wsgi.py", line 180, in _get_post
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     self._load_post_and_files()
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/http/__init__.py", line 372, in _load_post_and_files
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     self._post, self._files = QueryDict(self.body, encoding=self._encoding), MultiValueDict()
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/http/__init__.py", line 328, in body
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     self._body = self.read()
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/http/__init__.py", line 384, in read
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     return self._stream.read(*args, **kwargs)
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/core/handlers/wsgi.py", line 98, in read
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     result = self.buffer + self._read_limited()
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]   File "/data/www/download.mozilla.org/tuxedo/vendor/lib/python/django/core/handlers/wsgi.py", line 92, in _read_limited
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error]     result = self.stream.read(size)
[Fri Dec 07 14:02:40 2012] [error] UnreadablePostError: request data read error
```

This is the only occurrence of this error that is in the logs on the bouncer cluster

I am filing this only as an informational bug, as when the script was rerun it succeeded.

issues.title: Remove "php" app
issues.body:
The "php" django app only exists for the tests it contains, but the tests are highly data dependent and are somewhat unlikely to still pass (I didn't try).

I suggest removing them.

issue_comments.body:
Good job! However, try entering a broken IP address (such as: "10.0.0.345"), you'll get a 500 error. Can you catch it and turn it into an error on the field in question?

r-
Looks like you might need to create a vendor library: http://playdoh.readthedocs.org/en/latest/packages.html
btw, the code looks good, r+
looks good! r+
Yeah I missed that too in my code review, arghl. Thanks for fixing it! r+
I think you need a South migration to add the new field to the database.
Looks good so far, minus the migration. I asked Brandon to talk to @Rik about how to create a South migration.

This looks good; what concerns me a little is that this won't run cleanly on our production server: It'll try and create the geoip tables and will fail doing that. But perhaps we can't assume this would work anyway. Thus, when asking IT to update production, you'll need to tell them what SQL to run.

Yes that would make things easier I think. Then it's up to you/IT to "fake" the initial migration before actually running the second one (there's a South command for pretending to run a migration as just marking it as "run").
All right this looks good to me. The duplicate query is a little sad, but ah well.
r+

Locking tables with DDL statements is true (sheeri surely knows more), though considering how small these tables are, it should be a nonissue. For huge tables, this is in fact a real issue if you can't access it for an hour or worse.
I like this! If you answer my question about the logic behind user.is_staff, then r+
Also, it looks you can't merge this automatically anymore, might have to rebase before landing
Yeah makes sense to default not to SSL. Most of our traditional mirrors don't support it.
This looks good now, thanks Jake. Looks like these are various tweaks presumably written by justdave for sentry and sentry viewer. Thanks for porting them!
Do you want to merge this yourself? Otherwise, @brandonsavage or @Rik ?

You want to put this into your home dir:

```
% cat ~/.gitignore
.DS_Store
```
r+
r+
I suggest you just do a protocol-relative link: `//gravatar.com...`. This way it'll work both on http and https just fine.

commit_comments.body:
Hm, I think the usual syntax is:

`-e git://....`

Take a look at zamboni's requirements files, for example.

review_comments.body: Would it make sense if you didn't query for the fallback region unless you need it? It'd save us a lot of DB queries, for all the cases when the primary region is not rejected.
Just curious: Does this have anything to do with this patch? (By all means keep it in)
great, thanks for fixing it.
Hm, I wonder if we can avoid hitting the DB twice for this?
nit-pick: alphabetize :)

I am not sure I understand the logic here, can you explain? This is decorated with the change_user permission. So once we get to this point, we know the active user is allowed to edit other users. However, if that user is a staff member (= has access to the admin pages in any way), then you reject them here?
I think you just want to call this `profile_edit`.
line-break, shoot for <= 78 characters per line.
You could just add a comment next to the `if` saying that a logged-in user wants to edit a staff user and that's not allowed.
Write "User Accounts"
(and edition is a release of a book)
Just remove the line then :)

uh, this indentation is off.

Also, I guess a comment wouldn't have hurt here.
These lines are too long. If you lint your python files, it'll tell you this too (I know I'm an offender also, but try to add line breaks where they make sense).
line breaks
imports in alphabetical order
might be a matter of personal preference, but if is not a function :)
Yeah, I could have explained that better. And I do realize that other people are not as strict about function calls vs. statements as I am.
I'd say it's bad style checking for a specific return string. Instead, I'd look at the HTTP response code (that's what it's for, after all), if you got a 200 then your API call worked.
same here, testing for specific error wording is not necessary if you're testing for the error number.
like pmac suggested, you want to use the error constants here.
not a mistake, but you don't have to put the closing parenthesis on a separate line.
good catch
They're not "special" in Python, but you don't want to mix single and double quotes all the time. Stick with one.
This is very cryptic
ugly. Thanks for removing it.
if you touch this line, might as well make those single quotes

Single quotes unless:
- your string contains single quotes, in which case `"don't"` is preferable over `\'`
- it's a docstring (those always have triple double quotes)
why?

settings.py is a misnomer in Django (here, anyway). But I forgot there's a settings-dist in tuxedo. I thought this project has a settings.py that has all the defaults and any and all local fixes are in `local_settings` instead. But it looks like I was wrong. In that case, go ahead :)

issue_comments.body: BTW I considered using https://pypi.python.org/pypi/basicauth/0.2 but upon inspecting the source I think it has the same exact issue :) I might send a patch that way, it handles a few edge cases so might be worth switching to.
thanks!
@fwenzel good call
@fwenzel I went ahead and rebased too since it's a trivial one-liner - look ok now?
thanks!
Makes sense, `dbread` just falls back to `dbwrite` if unset so this is why this worked before. Let's test on dev
r+, these all seem sensible to me. @gozer do you want to rebase?
r+
Oops, sorry I meant to say squash down to one commit + rebase :) Or we can merge all 7 commits, up to you.
r+
@gozer wfm!
@gozer looks like you need to resolve some merge conflicts though
lgtm
r+

review_comments.body:
why is the `bool(... == "true")` necessary, isn't this enough?

```
ssl_only = request.POST.get('ssl_only', False)
```

? Is it because if `ssl_only` is set it'll be type `str` not `bool`?

So I think the nice way to do this would be with django forms (`BooleanField`), but I think this version of django is too old and still treats it as `str` (looks like it was fixed in 1.3, tuxedo is still 1.2) ... can wait until we upgrade, lgtm

Oh I have a branch where I fixed the PHP tests and also got most of the Django tests working, but I split it up to get the PHP ones running on jenkins and left this bit in (the `jenkins.sh` will copy `settings.py-dist` to `settings.py` and modify it)

Also, you pretty much never want to accidentally check this in, right?

commits.message: Add support for modifying locations.
report the X-Cache header, if any, about cache hit/miss

When we found an IP for the hostname in the URL, explicitely use it when making requests.

This way, whe know specifically which IP we are connecting to for the mirror.
record the IPs we see
Report actual time taken for each request.

review_comments.body: Nope
Having the error numbers hardcoded in multiple places is a code smell.
(Try and define these somewhere with meaningful names and use those instead)
non useful comment
weird way to do a LIMIT 1 but ok
Once we have the actual product name here, there is no need to redirect. We can just proceed to finding a valid mirror at this point.
I really dislike this idiom, fwiw
And to be clear, I mean where the except block is the expected behavior, and the mainline is the exception. Yuck.
I would honestly prefer to fix it now - this part is pretty self contained
Why not built in microtime()? You need to pass true to get it as a float.
it returns bool, below
Consider deleting sdo itself while you're at it...just clutters up the repo

commits.message:
Longer max-age

There's no longer any reason why this can't be cached for a longer interval. This change increases our LB cache hit rate from about 90% to 93-94%, which is a 30-40% reduction in load on the backend servers.

Still don't want to go *too* high, as it will start to elongate the time between when a release is created and when it becomes available.

Merge pull request #22 from nthomas-mozilla/ssl-only

Bug 809229, show ssl_only in product listing UI

Merge pull request #23 from nthomas-mozilla/sentry-sql

Bug 777516, Adjust sql definition for changing sentry_log.reason to mediumtext

issue_comments.body:
Hmm... I'm no expert, but the "default = True" line concerns me a bit.... I believe new products are often added in a programmatic way, which currently doesn't know about this setting. that means new "update" products would get added and have this set by default, but we aren't planning to serve updates via HTTPS due to cost. We could of course change whatever code is currently doing that, but I don't know what/where that is or how complicated it might be to implement such a change.

Am I misunderstanding?
Looks good to me. Thanks!
Thanks!
r+ on the perl code
Going to close this out for cleanliness... we no longer use the GeoIP functionality of bouncer, ever since switching to CDN-based product delivery.
Seems simple/obvious enough to me... merging!

review_comments.body:
This chooses which locale should be tested. Historically we test the alphabetically last locale available, because rsync generally runs in alphabetical order... the thinking is that if the last locale exists, then the other do too. It's inherently a trade-off designed to avoid having to test every single locale individually.

I read this as "if seamonkey, and if it's version 2.0.5 or 2.0.6, check zh-CN. For all other versions, check tr".

Based on wandering around here: http://download.cdn.mozilla.net/pub/seamonkey/releases/ ... it appears that Seamonkey did indeed have zh-CN support for those two versions, and potentially a few others. However it was not consistent. 2.1 did not have it... 2.13 (current) has zh-CN and zh-TW. In many versions, "tr" was indeed the alphabetically-last locale.

However, for the most part it doesn't matter anymore. The lone mirrors are reverse-proxying CDNs, not rsync-based. The logic of checking the last locale no longer holds any real value... any locale is just as good as any other. We still need to check _a_ locale, but it doesn't matter which one.

Adding Jake Maul's patch to reduce overall server load by letting Zeus cache for a short period.

Preparing the code to be more easily unit testing in accordance with
our choice to unit test Bouncer. The following tasks were completed:

* Changing functions to be in a separate file to facilitate testing.

  creation of a mock SDO object to uncouple Bouncer from a database
  during testing.
* The implementation of a recursive, stand-alone function for the
  querying of mirrors in the database, to facilitate testing this
  important functionality.

FALSE. This will help clean up the logs in production and make it
easier to see actual problems as they are happening.

review_comments.body: It was the only way I could get the PIP requirements to install. It doesn't have anything to do with this patch other than that.

That's actually intentional. The $client_ip variable is referenced before it's used elsewhere in the code. PHP doesn't consider this a fatal error, but does emit a notice, which I corrected by initializing the variable before it would be referenced by other code. This will be overwritten later when it discovers the client IP address.

Since the alias name is unique, there can't ever be more than one, so a LIMIT 1 would be redundant in this case.

issue_comments.body:
It's an r+ from me :cake: Thanks for fixing all the things!

Squarsh and merge at will (as long as @lauraxt agrees).

This is a great start! Thanks @brandonsavage. :cake: 

That said, I do still see some issues thanks to the handy-dandy flake8 program:

``` bash
(tuxedo) ± flake8 --ignore=E121,E123,E124,E125,E126,E127,E128,E501 --exclude=migrations apps
apps/api/urls.py:1:1: F403 'from django.conf.urls.defaults import *' used; unable to detect undefined names
apps/api/tests/__init__.py:1:1: F403 'from test_general import *' used; unable to detect undefined names
apps/api/tests/__init__.py:2:1: F403 'from test_products import *' used; unable to detect undefined names
apps/api/tests/__init__.py:3:1: F403 'from test_locations import *' used; unable to detect undefined names
apps/api/tests/test_products.py:28:56: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
apps/api/tests/test_products.py:47:63: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
apps/api/tests/test_products.py:90:64: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
apps/api/tests/test_products.py:104:64: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
apps/api/tests/test_products.py:117:64: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
apps/api/tests/test_products.py:131:64: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
apps/api/tests/test_products.py:142:50: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
apps/mirror/urls.py:1:1: F403 'from django.conf.urls.defaults import *' used; unable to detect undefined names
```

The ones from `apps.api/tests/__init__.py` are unavoidable. So flake8 let's you add `# noqa` at the end of the lines to skip those as "yeah yeah, I know." If you're not interested in including flake8 into your CI then you don't need to do that, but I think style checking in CI is awesome.

yaaarrrrrrr+

:+1:

Looks good. One small NIT is that the test doesn't have a doc string, and if one were to be added including a reference to this bug would be nice.

The other NIT is that the commit message doesn't conform to [our standard](http://mozweb.readthedocs.org/en/latest/git.html#commit-messages) of using active voice (Fix instead of Fixes) nor length of the first line with further explanation after a blank line.

These are style things though and up to you since it's your project.

r+

review_comments.body: non-specific except blocks should be avoided. This should be `except Product.DoesNotExist:`
This is implied with all Django models.
One blank line between methods.
Why not use a ForeignKey here?
Also space around the equals sign.
Might consider `db_index=True` here.

This would be more efficient as an `exists()` query as it doesn't fetch the whole record nor create an object:

``` python
if not Product.objects.filter(name=self.cleaned_data['related_product']).exists():
    raise forms.ValidationError("The product you entered was invalid")

return self.cleaned_data['related_product']
```
Don't seem to be using this variable. This is another good candidate for an `exists()` query.

I believe this could all just be a `get_or_create`:

``` python
alias_obj, created = ProductAlias.objects.get_or_create(alias=alias, defaults={'related_product': redirect})
if not created:
    # assuming you want to update the redirect if it already exists.
    alias_obj.related_product = redirect
    alias_obj.save()
```
Use an exists query here as well.
This should make the save fail since the field doesn't allow Null. Is that what you intend?
Another good exists() spot.
Doc string or some comments would be helpful for this one.
This comment was mostly for you :) A comment here is good, but the wording is odd for the context.
Either this or the south migration are probably superfluous. I can't imagine having both is good.

Ah. Yes. Though modifying the admin form to use a text field instead of a select isn't that hard if you still wanted to use a real relationship. I'm sure queries on the PHP side could still be crafted for speed. Up to you though.
should be 2 blank lines here.
2 blank lines here too
Just 2 blank lines here.

I 2nd this. Something like:

``` python
class ERRORS:
    alias_required = 101
    product_required = 102
    product_invalid = 103
    alias_invalid = 104
```

Or go even simpler and make them all constants:

``` python
E_ALIAS_REQUIRED = 101
E_PRODUCT_REQUIRED = 102
...
```
Should have tests for each error state as well. Some tests of the custom clean methods on the admin form would be sweet as well. Code coverage FTW! :cake:
I think he means he prefers a space between: `if ($alias) {`.
These should be defined at the module level so they can be imported and used elsewhere (e.g. in the tests).

These values should be validated in some way. I believe django does some automatic DB sanitation of strings passed to the ORM, but I wouldn't trust only that, and it'd be a lot better to avoid sending invalid queries to the DB.
Our rule is to generally stick with single quotes unless you need doubles for some reason (like there are single quotes in the string).
